newsitem.title: USA: Russia heads for 3 pct GDP growth in 1997 - IMF.
newsitem.headline: Russia heads for 3 pct GDP growth in 1997 - IMF.

text.p: Russian gross domestic product could grow by three percent this year after a decline of 2.8 percent in 1996, the International Monetary Fund said in its World Economic Outlook on Wednesday.
The IMF said it expected Russian annual inflation to slide to a post-reform low of 14 percent, from 48 percent last year.

"The government's fiscal position in Russia remains fragile, with revenue collection particularly weak, but recent indicators suggest that the long-awaited recovery of output may materialize in 1997," the IMF said.

The Washington-based organisation has already delayed handing over several monthly tranches of a $10 billion three-year loan to Russia because it is worried about low tax collection, and a team is in Moscow this week to look at the latest economic figures.

IMF Chief Economist Michael Mussa, forecasting growth this year, praised Russia's performance in bringing interest rates down and said tight monetary policies were providing a good basis for sustained long-term growth.

"Other countries that have not pursued such sound monetary policies as successfully as Russia have been much less successful in reducing inflation and (Russia is) thereby providing a better basis for sustained growth in the long term," he told a news conference.

"Because of the relatively weak fiscal situation, credit to the private sector has recently tightened and that has been a factor that has retarded a move to positive output. We are expecting to see that this year."

The Russian economy has contracted stubbornly since the country launched its market-oriented reform programme in 1992, but officials are tentatively forecasting GDP growth of around two percent this year.
In neighbouring Ukraine, the IMF forecast growth of 2.7 percent, after a 10 percent decline last year. It said inflation would fall to 25 percent, from 80 percent in 1996.

"Progress has been made with privatizing large- and medium-scale enterprises in the last two years, but the pace has slowed down in early 1997 and regulatory uncertainty continues to impede market activity," the report said.
